name: deusoma
text: I gave that comment a chubby. And then I thought about it, and drowned in irony.

name: snowman
text: A comment left by snowman was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by Afterward, lamboyster, fakead, Deusoma, NotGodot, willt)

text: Damn lame allotment.... There should be a special reserve for pedantry.

text:

text: Iron chubbies are better chubbies.

text: Y.O.U.R.-F.A.U.L.T.

name: ambala
text: I can't remember why Phillipe doesn't live w/his mom - is that ever answered?

name: lastlarf
text: I don't think we learn much about his past other than this strip, and that something so bad happened when he was a pup that he has to dunk his arm in a toilet for half an hour as therapy.

name: spectre
text: According to Phillipe in RECIPES FOR A LADY OR A MAN: THE ACHEWOOD COOKBOOK, "Mother lives in Iowa now". And some idiot decided a household containing Lyle was the way to go. (Another thing from the COOKBOOK: the lived in a 100-year-old farmhouse which they ha to sell when Father died; then it burned down because the new owners were careless.)

name: rowboat
text: To every character his Circumstances.

name: orvel
text: Everyone has a sob story.

name: anomalous3
text: Because she'll beat him with wire hangers

name: vice
text:
OR her belt.

If he's been REALLY bad she'll use the buckle

name: orvel
text: No. Wire. Hangers. EVER.

text: when an otter turns five, he knows it's time.

name: saint
text:
How long has he been 5 though?
Do otters age incredibly slowly or something?

name: lordparadise
text: Philippe is five.

name: madnes
text: I love the way he looks down at his feet, trying to work out if he's grown.

text: That is kind of exactly what I was going to say . . . it almost looks like an embarrassing compliment kind of shuffle though . . .

name: skiddyfisk
text: The incident is so traumatizing that he grew eyebrows so he could raise them in shock.

name: honesttom
text: This strip actually made me sad the first time I read it.

name: _cheesekayke
text: Philippe is so cute in panel 3. That is totally what kids talking on the phone to their daddies at work look like.

text: As an artist, the alt text was the funniest part of the strip for me.

name: hellofyellin
text: It is a perfect... table!

name: sticks
text: I feel the same way about some of the nude models I've drawn.

name: dans
text: Alternate ending interpretation: Phillipe goes back to his room to discover someone has painted a hurtful name on the wall. Phillipe is pissed.

name: orvel
text: ...with glow-in-the-dark paint.

name: milkpants
text: table's good

name: unsentletter
text: Purely unexpected after all the dick jokes.  So sorry, Phillipe...

name: snowman
text: This strip is brilliant, and not at all funny. 5.

name: girlandagun
text: I think my favorite Achewood strips embody both those qualities.

name: rbisme
text: spontaneous combustingly sad

name: lux
text: huuugs!

name: hamscout
text:
I wish I had this comic to comfort me back when my parents got divorced...
The thought that a 5-year-old stuffed otter could get through it might have given me strength.

...or, maybe I would have just stood on the drum machine instructions...

name: tekende
text:
Your comment reminded me of a time from childhood. My little brother checked out a book from the library because it had cute drawings of dinosaurs in it, and was laid out sort of like a comic book. Turned out it was a book to help children understand and deal with their parents' divorce. My parents were not divorcing and are in fact still together. Hilarious.

I read a little bit of that book though, out of curiosity. It was really sad.

name: quantumcasaba
text: Oh my god, it's still heartbreaking upon revisiting.

name: cyberia
text: I love the third panel where Philippe is looking at his foot.

name: kikineko
text: Oh so cute Philippe is.  But I'm wondering what he is crying about... is it thinking about his dead father or his mother having a new man in her life?

name: tekende
text: Both!

name: puguglypress
text:
Deep down, we all still feel this way, every second of our lives.

...right?
